title: 'Stormzy effect' sees record 91 black students enrol at Cambridge University this year
text:
The proportion of black students among Cambridge freshers reflects the UK population for the first time.

A record 91 black students were admitted to the university this year, a rise of almost 50 per cent on last year's intake of 61.

It means 3.4 per cent of the 2,663 students enrolling in 2019 were black –up from 2.1 per cent in 2018.

The proportion of black students among Cambridge freshers reflects the UK population for the first time as a record 91 students were admitted to the university

Yesterday, university bosses said the rise may have been partially due to the 'Stormzy effect'.

The singer announced last year he would fund tuition fees and living costs for two students each year for the duration of their studies at Cambridge.

University bosses said the rise may have been partially due to the 'Stormzy effect'

A spokesman said: 'Since then the university has seen an increase in the number of black students engage in its outreach activities and enquire about its courses.'

In the latest national census, taken in 2011, black people made up 3 per cent of the UK population, including Northern Ireland and Scotland.

It means the percentage admitted to Cambridge this year has surpassed that milestone for the first time.

Senior pro-vice-chancellor Professor Graham Virgo said yesterday: 'The university has worked hard to get the message out that it is a welcoming place for students regardless of their ethnicity.

'This record rise in the number of black students is a credit to their hard work and ability – we have not lowered entry standards.'
description: There was a rise in the number of black students admitted to Cambridge of almost 50 per cent compared to last year's 61. It means the 3.4 per cent of the students enrolling in 2019 were black.
